facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 672 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgement and decree dated October 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 8 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 672 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgement and decree dated October 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 8 of 1960.

facts.text: The suit was decreed by the Trial Court but reversed by the High Court which dismissed the appellant's suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the Trial Court but, on appeal, the High Court reversed the decree and dismissed the appellants suit.

facts.text: On December 24, 1956, respondent No. 2 purchased at the public auction sale held by the Divisional Forest Officer, Harda, the cut timber and arkat trees of Coupe No. 9 Eastern, East Kalibhit Range, in Harda Forest Division, for Rs. 70,200.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted facts of the case are that on December 24, 1956, respondent No. 2 purchased at the public auction sale held by the Divisional Forest Officer, Harda, the cut timber and arkat trees of companype No. 9 Eastern, East Kalibhit Range, in Harda Forest Division, for Rs. 70,200.

facts.text: The appellant stood surety for the purchaser, respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant stood surety for the purchaser, viz., respondent No. 2.

facts.text: The purchase price was to be paid in four instalments: Rs. 17,600 at once (paid), others due March 1, May 15, December 15, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase price was to be paid in four instalments, according to para 4 of the deed of compantract. Rs. 17,600 were to be paid at once and were so paid. The other instalments were due on March 1, May 15 and December 15, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 did not pay the instalments due on March 1, May 15 and December 15, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: These instalments were number paid by respondent No. 2 and hence respondent No. 1 took proceedings against the appellant for the recovery of the amount.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 took proceedings against the appellant for recovery of the amount.

anchor.surface_text: These instalments were number paid by respondent No. 2 and hence respondent No. 1 took proceedings against the appellant for the recovery of the amount.

facts.text: Boundary certificate Exhibit D-1 furnished on February 5, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This certificate, Exhibit D-1, was furnished on February 5, 1957 and stated that the respondent No. 2 had clearly understood the boundaries of the areas companered by the lease

facts.text: Appellant Badri Prasad signed the boundary certificate as a witness.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Badri Prasad signed this certificate as a witness.

facts.text: Work to continue up to June 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The work companld companue upto June 30, 1958.

facts.text: Formal deed of contract signed by Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The formal deed of compantract was signed by the Chief Conser- vator of Forests on May 3, 1957 and the preamble of the deed gives the date of the making of the compantract to be May 3, 1957.

facts.text: First Schedule signed by contractor respondent No. 2 and Divisional Forest Officer on December 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This is signed by the compantractor, respondent No. 2 and by the Divisional Forest Officer, Harda Division, dated December 24, 1956.

facts.text: Trace of the coupe sold signed by respondent No. 2 and Divisional Forest Officer on November 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The trace of the companype sold was signed by respondent No. 2 and the Divisional Forest Officer on November 29, 1956, prior to the actual auction sale.

facts.text: Third Schedule signed by respondent No. 2, appellant (surety) and Divisional Forest Officer on December 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Third Schedule relating to the out. turn register was also signed by respondent No. 2 and, by the appellant who stood surety and the Divisional Forest Officer, on December 24, 1956.

facts.text: Security bond signed by appellant on December 29, 1956, by Divisional Forest Officer on March 30, 1957, countersigned by Chief Conservator on May 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The security bond was signed by the appellant on December 29, 1956 and by the Divisional Forest Officer on March 30, 1957 and was companyntersigned by the Chief Conservator on May 3, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 began operations in section A of the coupe in the last week of February 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2, the compantractor, began his operations in section A of the companype in the last week of February, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 defaulted in payment of second instalment due March 1, 1957, did not pay till April 25, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He defaulted in the payment of the second instalment which was due on March 1, 1957 and did number pay that amount till April 25, 1957, though it was demanded several times from him.

facts.text: Notice Exhibit P4 issued to respondent No. 2 on March 23, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1957 a numberice. Exhibit P4, was issued to him.

facts.text: On April 25, 1957, appellant was told by forest authorities that no further removal allowed due to default.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1957 the appellant was told by the forest authorities that numberfurther removal of the forest produce would be allowed in view of the default of payment of the second instalment.

facts.text: Licence book and transit pass taken back by Government Forester Madanlal Pagare.

anchor.surface_text: The licence book and the transit pass were taken back by the Government Forester, Madanlal Pagare.

facts.text: Fire broke out in the forest and the cut timber sold to respondent No. 2 was burnt; report Exhibit D2 dated April 29, 1957 signed by contractor and Forest Guard Sheoprasad Parashar.

anchor.surface_text: Fire broke out in the forest and the cut timber sold to res- pondent No. 2 was burnt. The report about the loss from fire is Exhibit D2 dated April 29, 1957 and is signed by the compantractor and Sheoprasad Parashar. the Forest Guard.

facts.text: As a result of the fire, goods purchased by respondent No. 2 and not removed ceased to exist.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the fire the goods purchased by respondent No. 2 and number removed by then, ceased to exist.

facts.text: Appellant claimed no possession of cut timber except section A, no transfer of property, not liable for 2nd,3rd,4th instalments.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sought to avoid his liability as surety for the number-payment of the amount inter-alia on the -round that the compantractor respondent No. 2 had number been put in possession of the cut timber sold to him except of such timber which had been in section A of companype No. 9, that therefore there had been numbertransfer of property in the timber sold to him and that he was therefore number liable for paying the amounts due on the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments.

facts.text: Fire broke out in the last week of April 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the property in the cut timber sold and existing in sections B, C and D of the companype had number passed to the compantractor before the fire broke out in the last week of April 1957

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 admitted paragraphs 5B and 5C of the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 admitted what was stated in paras 5 B   C  of the plaint. It denied the understanding as averred in para 5 A

facts.text: Court found the goods sold were specific goods as felled trees had butt mark.

anchor.surface_text: The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly companplied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.

facts.text: No provision in contract or rules that possession not delivered till instalments paid.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the compantract that possession would number be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules, extracted earlier, do number companain any such restriction.

facts.text: Chief Conservator's signature on May 3, 1957 relates back to date of auction.

anchor.surface_text: His formal signature on the deed of compantract relates back the compantract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted and he and the Divisional Forest Officer signed the compantract.

facts.text: Property in the goods passed to respondent No. 2 at the time the contract was made.

anchor.surface_text: the property in the goods did pass at the time when the compantract was made. This section would have applied even if the time of payment of price hand been postponed.

facts.text: Appellant's suit rightly dismissed by High Court; Supreme Court dismisses appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

issues.text: Whether the property in the cut timber sold and existing in sections B, C and D of the coupe had passed to the contractor before the fire broke out in the last week of April 1957

anchor.surface_text: The main question urged before us is that the property in the cut timber sold and existing in sections B, C and D of the coupe had not passed to the contractor before the fire broke out in the last week of April 1957 and this contention is based on the facts that the goods sold were not specific goods as they had not been hammer-marked, that the goods in sections B, C and D could not be delivered till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments had been paid and that the deed of contract was signed after the fire had taken place.

issues.text: Whether the goods sold were specific goods given the absence of certain hammer marks

anchor.surface_text: The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly complied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.

issues.text: Whether there could be delivery of possession over the produce sold and existing in sections B, C and D till the various instalments had been paid

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the contract that possession would not be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules, extracted earlier, do not contain any such restriction.

issues.text: Whether the fact that the contract was signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957 after the fire affected the passing of property

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the contract was signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957, after fire had broken out has no effect on the question of delivery of possession of the produce sold and consequently on the passing of property in the goods to the contractor respondent No. 2.

issues.text: Whether r. 8 of the Forest Contract Rules reserved the right of disposal such that s. 25(1) of the Sale of Goods Act applied and property did not pass

anchor.surface_text: The other point urged by Mr. Agarwala, for the appellant, is that in view of r. 8 of the Forest Contract Rules which empowered the Divisional Forest Officer to stop the removal of forest produce sold on his finding that the value of the forest produce already removed by the contractor exceeded the amount of the instalments already paid by him, the seller in this case had reserved the right of disposal of the forest produce until certain conditions were fulfilled and that therefore s. 25 (1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 (Act III of 1930) applies to the facts of the case

issues.text: Whether s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act applied to pass property upon making of the unconditional contract for specific goods in deliverable state

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, it is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case. This section provides that where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods or both is postponed.

issues.text: Whether the Chief Conservator's signature after the fire could relate back or ratify given the goods had ceased to exist
Whether possession of goods in each section was to be delivered only on payment of each instalment

anchor.surface_text: It was averred by the appellant in paragraph 5 A of the plaint Thus it was clearly understood on both sides and also explained by the Forest Department officials of defendant No. 1 and which has been all along implicit in the contract as per usual practices of the forest department that the possession of the goods of each respective section will be delivered to the Contractor on payment of each instalment as stated above.

arguments.claim: The contractor respondent No. 2 had not been put in possession of the cut timber sold to him except of such timber which had been in section A of coupe No. 9, that therefore there had been no transfer of property in the timber sold to him and that he was therefore not liable for paying the amounts due on the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sought to avoid his liability as surety for the non-payment of the amount inter-alia on the ground that the contractor respondent No. 2 had not been put in possession of the cut timber sold to him except of such timber which had been in section A of coupe No. 9, that therefore there had been no transfer of property in the timber sold to him and that he was therefore not liable for paying the amounts due on the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments.

arguments.court_reasoning: No provision in contract or r.18 restricting possession/delivery until instalments paid; operations regulated separately from payments.

arguments.claim: In view of r. 8 of the Forest Contract Rules empowering stoppage of removal if value removed exceeds payments, the seller reserved right of disposal until conditions fulfilled, so s.25(1) Sale of Goods Act applies and property did not pass.

anchor.surface_text: The other point urged by Mr. Agarwala, for the appellant, is that in view of r. 8 of the Forest Contract Rules which empowered the Divisional Forest Officer to stop the removal of forest produce sold on his finding that the value of the forest produce already removed by the contractor exceeded the amount of the instalments already paid by him, the seller in this case had reserved the right of disposal of the forest produce until certain conditions were fulfilled and that therefore s. 25 (1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 (Act III of 1930) applies to the facts of the case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e last companytention raised for the appellant is that as the companytract was signed by the Chief Conservator about a week after the goods lying in s

arguments.court_reasoning: No reservation in contract or rules; r.8 enforces statutory lien under s.83 Indian Forest Act (first charge), regulatory not contractual; instalments deemed full payment at delivery.

arguments.claim: As the contract was signed by the Chief Conservator about a week after the goods lying in sections B, C and D had been burnt by fire, the contract must be deemed to have been not made at all by the Chief Conservator who could not have contracted to sell goods which did not exist; no ratification after loss possible.
arguments.court_reasoning: Ratification/relation back possible even after loss (analogy to marine insurance precedents); no prejudice to third party; contract contemplated risk of loss per r.32.

arguments.claim: Respondent No. 1 admitted paras 5B and 5C regarding no removal until hammer-marked, checked, signed, and depot examination.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 admitted what was stated in paras 5 B and C of the plaint. It denied the understanding as averred in para 5 A

arguments.claim: The felled trees sold were specific goods due to butt marks and presumed compliance with felling rules.

anchor.surface_text: The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly complied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.

arguments.claim: No restriction in contract or r.18 on delivery of possession of sections B,C,D until instalments paid.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the contract that possession would not be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules, extracted earlier, do not contain any such restriction.

arguments.claim: Chief Conservator's formal signature on May 3, 1957 relates back to date of auction; completes execution, not ratification of unauthorized act.

anchor.surface_text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted and he and the Divisional Forest Officer signed the contract.

arguments.claim: s.20 Sale of Goods Act applies: unconditional contract for specific goods in deliverable state; property passes when contract made, even if payment/delivery postponed; instalments deemed full payment.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, it is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case. This section provides that where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods or both is postponed.

arguments.claim: r.8 Forest Contract Rules enforces statutory lien under s.83 Indian Forest Act; regulatory right to stop removal, not contractual reservation of disposal right under s.25 SOGA.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the deed of contract or in the Forest Contract Rules which reserved such a right of disposal in the State. Right given to the Government under r. 8 is the right to stop the removal of forest produce when the value of the forest produce already removed exceeded the amount of the instalments paid. ... Reference may here be made to the provisions of s. 83 of the Indian Forest Act, 1927 ...

arguments.claim: Ratification/relation back valid even after loss of goods; analogous to marine insurance cases where ratification post-loss allowed; no prejudice to third parties; contract contemplated fire risk per r.32.
r.32 Forest Contract Rules: no compensation for loss by fire etc.; supports no relief where property had passed.

holdings.text: The goods sold therefore were specified goods.

anchor.surface_text: The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly complied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Felled trees had butt mark and matching stem mark; presumption of compliance with felling rules under Forest Manual makes them ascertained/specific despite lack of further marks.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the contract that possession would not be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules... do not contain any such restriction.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the contract that possession would not be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules, extracted earlier, do not contain any such restriction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of contract and r.18 shows regulation of operations (cutting/carting sequence) unrelated to instalment payments; no explicit restriction on possession/delivery.

holdings.text: The fact that the contract was signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957, after fire had broken out has no effect on the question of delivery of possession... and consequently on the passing of property.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the contract was signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957, after fire had broken out has no effect on the question of delivery of possession of the produce sold and consequently on the passing of property in the goods to the contractor respondent No. 2.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signature completes standard execution procedure after provisional auction acceptance; relates back to auction date per executive instructions.

holdings.text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted.

anchor.surface_text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted and he and the Divisional Forest Officer signed the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Divisional Officer had authority for auction/provisional acceptance; Chief Conservator's signature completes execution, not ratification of unauthorized act; per Forest Manual instructions.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the deed of contract or in the Forest Contract Rules which reserved such a right of disposal in the State.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the deed of contract or in the Forest Contract Rules which reserved such a right of disposal in the State. Right given to the Government under r. 8 is the right to stop the removal of forest produce when the value of the forest produce already removed exceeded the amount of the instalments paid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.8 enforces statutory lien under s.83 Indian Forest Act for amounts due; regulatory stoppage of removal, not contractual reservation of disposal right triggering s.25(1) SOGA.

holdings.text: [I]t is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case... the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods... is postponed.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, it is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case. This section provides that where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods or both is postponed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unconditional contract for specific goods in deliverable state; instalment payments deemed full at delivery per rules; property passes at contract formation.

holdings.text: [T]he property in the goods did pass at the time when the contract was made.

anchor.surface_text: They were in a deliverable state and therefore the property in the goods did pass at the time when the contract was made. This section would have applied even if the time of payment of price had been postponed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Culmination: specific goods (h1), no delivery restriction (h2), contract date relates back (h3), no s.25 reservation (h5), s.20 directly applies.

holdings.text: [T]his is the general proposition and will not be applicable to this case as no third person is being prejudiced...
holdings.reasoning_summary: General ratification time limit inapplicable absent prejudice to third party; anomalous marine insurance exception allows post-loss ratification, analogous here.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All defenses rejected; property passed pre-fire, surety liable for unpaid instalments.

precedents.citation: Williams v. North China Insurance Co. 1 L.R. 1876 1 C.P.D. 757

anchor.surface_text: Williams v. North China Insurance Co. 1 this proposition was sought to be reviewed. Cockburn C.J. said at p. 764 The existing authorities certainly show that when an insurance is effected without authority by one person on anothers behalf, the principal may ratify the insurance even after the loss is known. Mr. Benjamin asked us, as a Court of Appeal, to review those authorities Where an agent effected an insurance subject to ratification, the loss insured against is very likely to happen before ratification, and it must be taken that the insurance so effected involves that possibility as the basis of the contract. It seems to me that, both according to authority and the principles of justice, a ratification may be made in such a case. These observations would fully apply to the facts of the present case, even if we were of the view that the Chief Conservator ratified the unauthorised act of the Divisional Forest Officer on May 3, 1957, after the fire had taken place.

precedents.case_name: Williams v. North China Insurance Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Ratification of an insurance contract effected without authority can be made by the principal even after knowledge of the loss, as the contract involves the possibility of loss before ratification.
precedents.cited_holding: The existing authorities certainly show that when an insurance is effected without authority by one person on anothers behalf, the principal may ratify the insurance even after the loss is known... a ratification may be made in such a case.

anchor.surface_text: The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly complied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the contract was signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957, after fire had broken out has no effect on the question of delivery of possession of the produce sold and consequently on the passing of property in the goods to the contractor respondent No. 2.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the deed of contract or in the Forest Contract Rules which reserved such a right of disposal in the State. Right given to the Government under r. 8 is the right to stop the removal of forest produce when the value of the forest produce already removed exceeded the amount of the instalments paid.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, it is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case. This section provides that where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods or both is postponed.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: They were in a deliverable state and therefore the property in the goods did pass at the time when the contract was made. This section would have applied even if the time of payment of price had been postponed.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal.
